title: Motion and Speed
subject: Physics
learning_objectives: Understand what motion means in physics

sections.title: What is Motion?
sections.content:
Motion is the change in position of an object with respect to time. When an object changes its position relative to a reference point, we say the object is in motion.

For example:
• A car moving on a road
• A bird flying in the sky
• Earth revolving around the Sun

Motion is always relative. A person sitting in a moving bus is at rest relative to the bus but in motion relative to the ground.

sections.title: Distance vs Displacement
sections.content:
**Distance** is the total path length traveled by an object. It is a scalar quantity (has only magnitude).

**Displacement** is the shortest distance between the initial and final positions. It is a vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction).

**Example:** If you walk 3 km east and then 4 km north:
• Distance = 3 + 4 = 7 km
• Displacement = 5 km (using Pythagoras theorem)

sections.title: Speed and Velocity
sections.content:
**Speed** = Distance / Time

Speed tells us how fast an object is moving. It is measured in meters per second (m/s) or kilometers per hour (km/h).

**Velocity** = Displacement / Time

Velocity tells us how fast and in which direction an object is moving.

**Example:** A car travels 100 km in 2 hours.
Speed = 100 km / 2 h = 50 km/h

sections.title: Types of Motion
sections.content:
**Uniform Motion:** When an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time.
Example: A car moving at constant 60 km/h on a highway.

**Non-uniform Motion:** When an object covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time.
Example: A car in city traffic, stopping and starting.

sections.title: Key Formulas
sections.content:
Speed = Distance / Time

Velocity = Displacement / Time

Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time

Average Velocity = Total Displacement / Total Time

key_points: Motion is the change in position with respect to time
Distance is total path length; displacement is shortest path
Speed is a scalar; velocity is a vector
Uniform motion has constant speed; non-uniform has varying speed

quiz_questions.question: What is the SI unit of speed?
quiz_questions.explanation: The SI unit of speed is meters per second (m/s).

quiz_questions.question: A car travels 150 km in 3 hours. What is its average speed?
Which quantity has both magnitude and direction?
quiz_questions.explanation: Displacement is a vector quantity with both magnitude and direction.

quiz_questions.question: If you walk in a complete circle back to your starting point, what is your displacement?
quiz_questions.explanation: Displacement is zero because the initial and final positions are the same.
